conclusion: Predicting liquid flow paths from containers A, B, C, and D to containers E, F, or G.
Container A is the mint/teal block at the top left.
Liquid drops straight down from A.
First, liquid encounters a gray baffle angled diagonally.
Liquid slides along the gray baffle toward the right.
Next, liquid encounters a green baffle also angled diagonally.
Liquid redirects along the green baffle, moving toward the left.
Following this path downward leads to container E.
Container B is the orange block, second from left.
Liquid drops straight down from B.
Liquid encounters the gray baffle.
Following along the gray baffle, the liquid moves rightward.
Liquid might then hit the light pink baffle.
The light pink baffle would direct it downward and slightly right.
This path leads toward container F.
Container C is the yellow block, middle.
Liquid drops straight down from C.
Liquid encounters the purple baffle.
The purple baffle directs it diagonally right and downward.
Liquid might hit the black baffle.
The black baffle redirects it slightly leftward.
This path appears to lead toward container F.
Container D is the pink block, far right.
Liquid drops straight down from D.
It wouldn't immediately hit any baffle.
Continuing downward, liquid would likely encounter the mint/teal and orange baffles at the bottom.
These baffles form part of container G.
